channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Arab Nations Vow Help ‘as Appropriate’ to Fight ISIS
item.description: The Obama administration is eager for the campaign against the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria to be perceived as a broad international effort that includes prominent Sunni states.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry in Jidda, Saudi Arabia, on Thursday. An American official said Mr. Kerry planned to discuss with the Saudis "in some detail'' plans to train and equip moderate rebels in Syria.

item.title: Video: Dying of Ebola at the Hospital Door
item.description: Monrovia, Liberia, is the first major metropolitan area to face an Ebola outbreak, and many of the infected there are left to die at the gates of overcrowded hospitals.
item.dc:creator: By BEN C. SOLOMON

item.title: Scottish Independence Backer Alleges ‘Bullying’ and Urges Inquiry
item.description: A week before the vote, Alex Salmond lashed out at anti-independence forces and called for an inquiry into reports that the Royal Bank of Scotland might move to England.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: Alex Salmond, speaking in Edinburgh on Thursday, appealed to Scots to "make history."

item.title: Peru Investigates the Killing of an Environmental Advocate
item.description: The advocate, Edwin Chota, and three other men were killed in a remote part of the Amazon jungle on their way to meet with leaders of another village in the region.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREA ZARATE and WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.media:description: with some of the 800 logs that he said were extracted illegally from his community in Peru.

item.title: Ebola Cases Double in Democratic Republic of Congo
item.description: The World Health Organization said that the number of Ebola cases in the country was 62, versus 31 a week earlier, and that more than half the afflicted patients had died.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Hamas Aide Hints at Softening on Direct Talks With Israel
item.description: With the next phase of Gaza talks stalled, a top Hamas official suggested that the group might have to reverse its ban on talking directly to Israel.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN and FARES AKRAM

item.title: News Analysis: Focus on ISIS Stirs Fears That Efforts to Curb Iran Will Recede
item.description: One mystery in President Obama’s decision to engage in a long battle to defeat ISIS is whether it will hurt or enhance the chances of preventing Iran from obtaining a nuclear weapon.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: European Union Pushes Forward With Tougher Sanctions on Russia
item.description: The measures, which will take effect on Friday, are meant to punish the country for its role in promoting separatist warfare in eastern Ukraine, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER and DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: Japanese Newspaper Retracts Fukushima Disaster Story and Fires Editor
item.description: The move comes a month after The Asahi Shimbun retracted a series of stories on another hot-button issue about Japan’s wartime legacy.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: The Asahi Shimbun was distributed on a Tokyo street last year.

item.title: U.N. Peacekeepers Released by Captors in Syria
item.description: The 45 peacekeepers, all from Fiji, were released from captivity in good condition after being held by the Syrian branch of Al Qaeda for nearly two weeks, the United Nations said.
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Signs of Hope in Chinese Attitudes Toward Japan
item.description: An annual survey showed a slight improvement in the way Chinese respondents view their Asian neighbors. However, in Japan, negative perceptions of China are at a record high in the study.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:credit: Sim Chi Yin for The New York Times
item.media:description: In 2012, Chinese protestors hurled plastic water bottles on the Japanese Embassy in Beijing after Japan nationalized islands claimed by both countries in the East China Sea.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: In China, a Search for Oscar Contenders
item.description: “Gone with the Bullets,” “Coming Home” and “Wolf Totem” are attracting notice as possible Academy Award entrants. A film from mainland China has yet to win an Oscar, and officials are eager for the cultural validation that the award would bring.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Jiang Wen at a news conference in Beijing for his film "Gone with the Bullets."

item.title: Rob Ford, Toronto Mayor, in Hospital With an Abdominal Tumor
item.description: After more than a year of political turmoil punctuated by his admission of crack cocaine use and drunken escapades, Mayor Rob Ford of Toronto was admitted to a hospital on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Obama Honors 9/11 Victims a Day After Announcing New Mission Against Terror
item.description: For President Obama, the anniversary lent historic and emotional resonance to his announcement Wednesday night of a new mission against the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER

item.title: Former South Korean Spy Chief Convicted in Online Campaign Against Liberals
item.description: The court found that Won Sei-hoon, former head of the National Intelligence Serivce, had violated a law barring the agency from domestic politics.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Won Sei-hoon, the former head of the National Intelligence Service, was sentenced to two and a half years in prison on Thursday for interfering in domestic politics.

item.title: Rebel Rivals of ISIS Fear U.S. Airstrikes Could Help Assad
item.description: There was intense debate on Thursday over whether airstrikes on ISIS would help or harm President Bashar al-Assad, his armed Syrian opponents and war-weary civilians.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, right, spoke with the United Nations envoy to Syria, Staffan de Mistura, in Damascus on Thursday.

item.title: Oscar Pistorius Not Guilty of Murder; Still Faces Lesser Homicide Charge
item.description: Judge Thokozile Matilda Masipa is expected to rule on Friday on the remaining charge of “culpable homicide” in the killing of Reeva Steenkamp.
item.dc:creator: By SARAH LYALL and ALAN COWELL

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Far From Home, Party Officials Feel the Stress, Study Finds
item.description: One of the Communist Party’s tools for curbing corruption — assigning officials to positions far from their homes — has inflicted emotional hardship and contributed to misdeeds, according to a new study.
item.category: Central Commission for Discipline Inspection (Communist Party of China)
item.dc:creator: By KIKI ZHAO
item.media:credit: Sim Chi Yin for The New York Times
item.media:description: A staff member clears lunchtime tables at a restaurant in Beijing that once was popular with officials. Those cadres are now under pressure to curb extravagance with public funds.

item.title: North Korea Returns a Defector to the South
item.description: Pyongyang said the 52-year-old man had entered the North through an unidentified third country to escape his economic difficulties in the capitalist South.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Scotland May Consign Great Britain to History
item.description: It may not be a bad thing if the Scots go it alone. But it’s still uncertain whether an independent Scotland would cut it.
item.dc:creator: By ROGER COHEN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Islamists Are Not Our Friends
item.description: The United States needs to be on the right side of a fault line that has opened between Islamists and non-Islamists.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By DENNIS B. ROSS

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: China's TV War Machine
item.description: World War II dramas give Beijing a handy propaganda tool to shore up patriotic fervor.
item.dc:creator: By PHILIP J. CUNNINGHAM

item.title: Chinese Journalists Describe Extortion Scheme
item.description: Several arrested journalists from the website 21st Century Net told how they had received money in return for having produced flattering articles or buried negative ones.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Austrian Court Unblocks Assets of Former U.S. Ambassador’s Wife
item.description: A lawyer for the former envoy, Zalmay Khalilzad, said a Viennese court had overturned a decision to freeze funds related to the transfer of nearly $1.5 million.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Drug Company Wins Approval to Make Generic Version of Viagra
item.description: A Chinese pharmaceutical company has received approval to become the country’s first official producer of a homegrown version of Viagra.
item.dc:creator: By BECKY DAVIS
item.media:description: A police officer in Beijing displayed fake Viagra seized in raids on counterfeiters. Soon, legal generic alternatives will be available in China.
